questiontext.text: In some game, each trial has a p=0.68p = 0.68 probability of success. A player will attempt 97 trials. What is the probability that the number of successes is less than 67.5?

generalfeedback.text:
We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. μ=np=(97)(0.68)=65.96\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (97)(0.68) ~=~ 65.96 σ=np(1−p)=(97)(0.68)(0.32)=4.5942573\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(97)(0.68)(0.32)} ~=~ 4.5942573

We determine a zz-score. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used ∑x\sum x to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use xx as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) z=x−μσ=67.5−65.964.5942573=0.3352011\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{67.5-65.96}{4.5942573} \\\\ &= 0.3352011 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(Z<0.3352011)=0.6312633P(Z < 0.3352011) ~=~ 0.6312633

Of course, you could have rounded zz, so the following will also get credit. P(Z<0.33)=0.6293P(Z < 0.33) ~=~ 0.6293 P(Z<0.34)=0.6331P(Z < 0.34) ~=~ 0.6331

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. μ=np=(154)(0.07)=10.78\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (154)(0.07) ~=~ 10.78 σ=np(1−p)=(154)(0.07)(0.93)=3.1662912\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(154)(0.07)(0.93)} ~=~ 3.1662912

We determine a zz-score. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used ∑x\sum x to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use xx as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) z=x−μσ=7.5−10.783.1662912=−1.0359123\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{7.5-10.78}{3.1662912} \\\\ &= -1.0359123 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(Z<−1.0359123)=0.1501215P(Z < -1.0359123) ~=~ 0.1501215

Of course, you could have rounded zz, so the following will also get credit. P(Z<−1.04)=0.1492P(Z < -1.04) ~=~ 0.1492 P(Z<−1.03)=0.1515P(Z < -1.03) ~=~ 0.1515

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the binomial distribution. μ=np=(166)(0.23)=38.18\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (166)(0.23) ~=~ 38.18 σ=np(1−p)=(166)(0.23)(0.77)=5.4220476\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(166)(0.23)(0.77)} ~=~ 5.4220476

We determine both zz-scores. (In the de Moivre-Laplace notes, I used ∑x\sum x to emphasize that a binomial variable is a sum of Bernoulli trials. Here, I will just use xx as the boundary for number of successes, because this is the more common notation.) We get the first zz-score.

z1=x1−μσ=39.5−38.185.4220476=0.2434505\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{x_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{39.5-38.18}{5.4220476} \\\\ &= 0.2434505 \end{aligned}

We get the second zz-score.

z2=x2−μσ=41.5−38.185.4220476=0.6123148\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{x_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{41.5-38.18}{5.4220476} \\\\ &= 0.6123148 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(0.2434505<Z<0.6123148)=0.1336635P(0.2434505 < Z < 0.6123148) ~=~ 0.1336635

Of course, you could have rounded the zz-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. P(0.24<Z<0.61)=0.1343P(0.24 < Z < 0.61) ~=~ 0.1343 P(0.25<Z<0.62)=0.1337P(0.25 < Z < 0.62) ~=~ 0.1337 P(0.24<Z<0.62)=0.1304P(0.24 < Z < 0.62) ~=~ 0.1304 P(0.25<Z<0.61)=0.1376P(0.25 < Z < 0.61) ~=~ 0.1376

questiontext.text: In some game, each trial has a p=0.27p = 0.27 probability of success. A player will attempt 149 trials. What is the probability that the proportion of successes is less than 0.3121?

generalfeedback.text:
We determine the mean and standard deviation of the proportion sampling distribution. μ=p=0.27\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.27 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.27)(0.73)n=0.0363706\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.27)(0.73)}{n}} ~=~ 0.0363706

We determine a zz-score. (The common notation is p̂\hat{p} for a specific proportion.) z=p̂−μσ=0.3121−0.270.0363706=1.1575291\begin{aligned} z &= \frac{\hat{p} - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.3121-0.27}{0.0363706} \\\\ &= 1.1575291 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(Z<1.1575291)=0.8764719P(Z < 1.1575291) ~=~ 0.8764719

Of course, you could have rounded zz, so the following will also get credit. P(Z<1.15)=0.8749P(Z < 1.15) ~=~ 0.8749 P(Z<1.16)=0.877P(Z < 1.16) ~=~ 0.877

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the proportion sampling distribution. μ=p=0.17\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.17 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.17)(0.83)106=0.0364847\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.17)(0.83)}{106}} ~=~ 0.0364847

We determine both zz-scores. We get the first zz-score.

z1=p̂1−μσ=0.1085−0.170.0364847=−1.6858975\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{\hat{p}_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.1085-0.17}{0.0364847} \\\\ &= -1.6858975 \end{aligned}

We get the second zz-score.

z2=p̂2−μσ=0.1745−0.170.0364847=0.1241152\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{\hat{p}_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.1745-0.17}{0.0364847} \\\\ &= 0.1241152 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(−1.6858975<Z<0.1241152)=0.5034802P(-1.6858975 < Z < 0.1241152) ~=~ 0.5034802

Of course, you could have rounded the zz-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. P(−1.69<Z<0.12)=0.5023P(-1.69 < Z < 0.12) ~=~ 0.5023 P(−1.68<Z<0.13)=0.5052P(-1.68 < Z < 0.13) ~=~ 0.5052 P(−1.69<Z<0.13)=0.5013P(-1.69 < Z < 0.13) ~=~ 0.5013 P(−1.68<Z<0.12)=0.5062P(-1.68 < Z < 0.12) ~=~ 0.5062

We determine the mean and standard deviation of the proportion sampling distribution. μ=p=0.74\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.74 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.74)(0.26)81=0.0487371\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.74)(0.26)}{81}} ~=~ 0.0487371

We determine both zz-scores. We get the first zz-score.

z1=p̂1−μσ=0.6481−0.740.0487371=−1.8846378\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{\hat{p}_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.6481-0.74}{0.0487371} \\\\ &= -1.8846378 \end{aligned}

We get the second zz-score.

z2=p̂2−μσ=0.7593−0.740.0487371=0.395166\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{\hat{p}_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.7593-0.74}{0.0487371} \\\\ &= 0.395166 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(−1.8846378<Z<0.395166)=0.6239004P(-1.8846378 < Z < 0.395166) ~=~ 0.6239004

Of course, you could have rounded the zz-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. P(−1.89<Z<0.39)=0.6223P(-1.89 < Z < 0.39) ~=~ 0.6223 P(−1.88<Z<0.4)=0.6253P(-1.88 < Z < 0.4) ~=~ 0.6253 P(−1.89<Z<0.4)=0.6216P(-1.89 < Z < 0.4) ~=~ 0.6216 P(−1.88<Z<0.39)=0.626P(-1.88 < Z < 0.39) ~=~ 0.626

Of course, you could have rounded the zz-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. P(0.47<Z<1.32)=0.2258P(0.47 < Z < 1.32) ~=~ 0.2258 P(0.48<Z<1.33)=0.2238P(0.48 < Z < 1.33) ~=~ 0.2238 P(0.47<Z<1.33)=0.2222P(0.47 < Z < 1.33) ~=~ 0.2222 P(0.48<Z<1.32)=0.2274P(0.48 < Z < 1.32) ~=~ 0.2274

questiontext.text: In some game, each trial has a p=0.29p = 0.29 probability of success. A player will attempt 72 trials. What is the probability that the proportion of successes is between 0.2847 and 0.3264?

generalfeedback.text:
We determine the mean and standard deviation of the proportion sampling distribution. μ=p=0.29\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.29 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.29)(0.71)72=0.0534764\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.29)(0.71)}{72}} ~=~ 0.0534764

We determine both zz-scores. We get the first zz-score.

z1=p̂1−μσ=0.2847−0.290.0534764=−0.0986936\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{\hat{p}_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.2847-0.29}{0.0534764} \\\\ &= -0.0986936 \end{aligned}

We get the second zz-score.

z2=p̂2−μσ=0.3264−0.290.0534764=0.6804667\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{\hat{p}_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.3264-0.29}{0.0534764} \\\\ &= 0.6804667 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(−0.0986936<Z<0.6804667)=0.2912047P(-0.0986936 < Z < 0.6804667) ~=~ 0.2912047

Of course, you could have rounded the zz-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. P(−0.1<Z<0.68)=0.2915P(-0.1 < Z < 0.68) ~=~ 0.2915 P(−0.09<Z<0.69)=0.2908P(-0.09 < Z < 0.69) ~=~ 0.2908 P(−0.1<Z<0.69)=0.2876P(-0.1 < Z < 0.69) ~=~ 0.2876 P(−0.09<Z<0.68)=0.2947P(-0.09 < Z < 0.68) ~=~ 0.2947

questiontext.text: In some game, each trial has a p=0.16p = 0.16 probability of success. A player will attempt 91 trials. What is the probability that the proportion of successes is between 0.1154 and 0.1593?

generalfeedback.text:
We determine the mean and standard deviation of the proportion sampling distribution. μ=p=0.16\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.16 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.16)(0.84)91=0.0384308\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.16)(0.84)}{91}} ~=~ 0.0384308

We determine both zz-scores. We get the first zz-score.

z1=p̂1−μσ=0.1154−0.160.0384308=−1.1609291\begin{aligned} z_1 &= \frac{\hat{p}_1 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.1154-0.16}{0.0384308} \\\\ &= -1.1609291 \end{aligned}

We get the second zz-score.

z2=p̂2−μσ=0.1593−0.160.0384308=−0.0171566\begin{aligned} z_2 &= \frac{\hat{p}_2 - \mu}{\sigma} \\\\ &= \frac{0.1593-0.16}{0.0384308} \\\\ &= -0.0171566 \end{aligned}

Then, find the standard normal probability.

P(−1.1609291<Z<−0.0171566)=0.3703205P(-1.1609291 < Z < -0.0171566) ~=~ 0.3703205

Of course, you could have rounded the zz-scores, so any of the following will also get credit. P(−1.17<Z<−0.02)=0.371P(-1.17 < Z < -0.02) ~=~ 0.371 P(−1.16<Z<−0.01)=0.373P(-1.16 < Z < -0.01) ~=~ 0.373 P(−1.17<Z<−0.01)=0.369P(-1.17 < Z < -0.01) ~=~ 0.369 P(−1.16<Z<−0.02)=0.375P(-1.16 < Z < -0.02) ~=~ 0.375
